Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of Novel Ligands for the Dscam Receptor in Axon Guidance
Award.AbstractNarration: In the developing embryo, growing nerves have to navigate long distances to find their targets and to connect up the nervous system. The individual fibers of the nerves are known as axons, and understanding how axons navigate is of great interest as it explains how the initial complexity of the brain and nervous system arises. Growing axons respond to cues in their environment that can either be attractive or repulsive; the same cues can also stimulate overall growth. The Down Syndrome Cell Adhesion Molecule (Dscam) gene is present in most organisms with a nervous system. Dscam unexpectedly allows axons to detect well-known navigational cues and to respond to them. The working model that drives much of the work in this proposal is that Dscam interprets the cues as attractive signals and stimulates axon growth towards the cues. This model is being tested in the fruit fly Drosophila using a genetic approach. The fruit fly nervous system is simple enough to observe the growth of single axons and to analyze how axons are affected when Dscam activity is reduced or absent. The results from the experiments will allow evaluation of whether all or part of the model is correct. The work is supported by experiments on tissue culture cells examining how Dscam and the cues physically interact. The project provides state of the art genetic and molecular biology training for both graduate and undergraduate students. The results derived from this study are expected to advance our knowledge of how axons grow and navigate in the fruit fly, as well as in many other nervous systems including the vertebrate spinal cord.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nervous systems can be compared to incredibly complex systems of electrical wiring as neurons connect with each other over long distances using structures called axons. A major knowledge gap lies in understanding how this wiring forms in the first place. Growing nerves use signals, generally known as ligands, in their environment to correctly navigate to their targets. Surprisingly, only a few of these ligands have been identified and it is not clear how such a small number of signals can generate something as complicated as a human brain. This project aimed to address part of this problem. Neurons respond to signals using proteins on their cell surface called receptors. These receptors steer the axon, causing it to grow towards or away from signal sources. There can be more than one receptor for a signal, and receptors can act in combination with each other. We studied a receptor called Dscam and demonstrated that signals binding to Dscam do not steer the nerve, but rather cause the nerve to grow (akin to stepping on a car’s accelerator). We focused on a signal called Slit that repels most growing nerves by binding a receptor called Robo. Slit can be cut into two pieces and we showed that one of these pieces called Slit-N can bind Dscam with and without the Robo receptor. The uncut Slit protein cannot bind Dscam, so our work helps us understand how Slit-N can have distinct biological activities including helping nerves grow and neurons survive. Slit-N has more diverse activities including blood vessel formation and preventing bleeding during Ebola infection, so our findings are likely to be relevant to a broad range of biological systems. The project provided training and research experience for numerous people at all stages of their careers, particularly undergraduates. Outreach consisted of bringing brains and nervous system exhibits to science and career fairs as well as classrooms, and is estimated to have reached several thousand people over the course of the project.
